block.p: Companies

The Air Force selected a team led by Lockheed to build a new generation of agile, radar-evading fighter planes. Also on the winning side are General Dynamics and Boeing; the losers are Northrop and McDonnell Douglas. [ Page A1. ]
Companies

The Air Force selected a team led by Lockheed to build a new generation of agile, radar-evading fighter planes. Also on the winning side are General Dynamics and Boeing; the losers are Northrop and McDonnell Douglas. [ Page A1. ]
By betting on Bank of New England, J. Terrence Murray is turning Fleet/Norstar into New England's biggest bank at a time of one of the region's worst downturns. [ D1. ]
The involvement of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts in the Bank of New England deal is certain to be widely debated. [ D7. ]
I.B.M. slashed PC prices, introduced models based on Intel's latest microprocessor and said it would outpace its rivals. [ D1. ]
RJR Nabisco announced a small profit, its first since going private in 1989. It posted net income of $5 million. [ D1. ]
Barclays de Zoete Wedd has abandoned its move into the American equities business after a little more than a year. [ D2. ]
American Express reached an agreement with Sumitomo Bank to issue charge cards and other consumer loans in Japan. [ D2. ]
NCR and A.T.& T. seemed to move closer to a deal, as NCR said it would accept A.T.& T.'s offer on certain conditions. [ D4. ]
A panel of Prudential directors reportedly approved offering Hardwick Simmons the top job at Prudential Securities. [ D4. ]
Texaco's net rose 26.5 percent, Chevron reported a gain of 17.8 percent, and Phillips Petroleum was off 38.2 percent. [ D8. ]
Morgan Stanley, Salomon, Alex. Brown and Piper Jaffray all reported sharply higher earnings. [ D8. ]
MCI said net income in the quarter fell 20.6 percent, to $130 million, despite strong revenue growth. [ D8. ]
Bethlehem Steel reported a first-quarter loss of $39.2 million, saying the recession had diminished demand for steel sheet. [ D8. ]
Times Mirror, the Tribune Co. and the Washington Post Co. reported large declines in earnings. [ D8. ]
NEC said it was negotiating with Bull about buying shares in the faltering French computer giant. [ D9. ]
E.D.S. and Continental signed a 10-year agreement under which E.D.S. will take over a large part of System One. [ D4. ] The Economy
The Supreme Court upheld a regulation that will make it easier for unions to organize at community hospitals. [ A1. ]
Greenspan said the economy's slide was drawing to an end and the central bank needed to be especially cautious on rate cuts. [ D1. ]
The fund that protects bank deposits is in far worse shape than has been reported, the G.A.O. has found. [ D1. ] Business Technology
The bar code is being groomed for a more demanding role after years of playing a bit part in the information revolution. [ D1. ] Markets
Stock prices moved slightly higher, ending a three-day losing streak. The Dow gained 2.73, to 2,930.45. [ D10. ]
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds posted a moderate recovery, pushing interest rates down slightly. [ D16. ]
Soybean futures prices surged after a Brazilian agency slashed its forecast for the soybean harvest. [ D17. ] The dollar fell. [ D17. ] Today's Columns
The latest report on the greenhouse effect is the first to bridge the canyon between alarmist science and what-me-worry economics. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ]
The rise in Texscan's stock appears to have been prompted by a firm's recommendation. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D10. ]
Roger Livingston and Paul Keye have rejected the comfortable life, choosing to form an agency in Los Angeles. Advertising. [ D18. ]
